(Prerequisites: MTH 1001, MTH 1010, SPS 1010, SPS 1020, PHY 1001, PHY 2091)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Observational Astronomy

courses.description: Provides the foundations of basic gravitation and orbital theory. Includes coordinate and timekeeping systems, the two-body problem, particle dynamics and motion under inverse square forces, particularly as applied to spacecraft orbit determinations, trajectories, time of flight and maneuvers. (Prerequisites: PHY 3011)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Orbital Mechanics

courses.description: Individual research directed by a faculty member. May not be used in place of any named courses in the major program. Requires the preparation and presentation of a report on the research. May be repeated for a maximum of four credits. (Requirements: GPA of 3.0 or higher, sophomore or higher standing, and instructor and department head approval.)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Research Exp in Space Sci

courses.description: Includes galactic coordinates, galactic rotation curve, N-body concepts and the virial theorem, Galactic formation and evolution, external galaxies, galaxy cluster evolution, Hubble's law and the distance scale, large-scale structure, cosmology and the particle physics connection. (Prerequisites: SPS 4010)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Astrophysics 2

courses.description: Studies the behavior of Earth's lower atmosphere, including an introduction to comparative planetology, atmospheric evolution, thermodynamics, dynamics, waves and turbulence, clouds, hurricanes, global circulation and global change. (Prerequisites: MTH 2201, MTH 3200, PHY 3060)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Physics of the Atmosphere

courses.description: Comprehensively surveys observations from both space-based and Earth-based experimentation, incorporated with the major planetary bodies, asteroids, comets and other small orbitals. Discusses both planetary interiors surface features and atmospheres. (Prerequisites: PHY 3060, PHY 3060, SPS 1020)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Comparative Planetology

courses.description: Covers interstellar and protoplanetary environments, formation and evolution of stars and planets, origin and evolution of life on Earth, terrestrial extremophiles, potentially habitable regions in the solar system, characteristics of extrasolar planets and habitable zones around stars. (Prerequisites: BIO 1020, MAR 1020, PHY 3060, SPS 1020)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Astrobiology

courses.description: Students conduct experiments in optics, atomic structure, nuclear and solid state physics that are basic to observations in space sciences. (Requirement: Senior standing in space sciences.)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Senior Laboratory

courses.description: Studies specific problems of space sciences. (Requirement: Department head approval.)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Spc Top in Space Sciences

courses.description: Includes reports and discussions on selected topics in contemporary, experimental and theoretical physics and space sciences. (Requirement: Student must be within three semesters of graduation.) (Q) (Prerequisites: SPS 4200)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Senior Seminar 2

courses.description: Individual study of specific problems in space sciences. (Requirement: Department head approval.)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Independent Study

courses.description: Individual research directed by a faculty member. (Requirement: Department head approval.)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Undergrad Research

courses.description: Includes formation and evolution of the Galaxy, including stellar populations and kinematics, spiral density theory; extragalactic astronomy, active galactic nuclei, Hubble's law, large-scale structure; and cosmology, including inflationary cosmology and the particle physics connection. (Requirement: Background knowledge in thermodynamics equivalent to PHY 3060.) (Prerequisites: PHY 5015)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Astrophysics 2

courses.description: Individual work under the direction of a member or members of the graduate faculty on a selected topic in space sciences. (Requirement: Department head approval.)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Thesis in Space Sciences

courses.description: Preparation for doctoral qualifying examination by individual studies under faculty supervision. (Requirement: Department head approval.)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Individual Studies

courses.description: Research leading to the doctoral dissertation. (Requirement: Department head approval.)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Research

courses.description: Preparation of doctoral dissertation. (Requirement: Admission to doctoral candidacy and department head approval.)
courses.subject: SPS
courses.title: Dissertation

courses.description: Examines systems principles for sustainable governance from fields including complexity theory, cybernetics, social networks and risk communications. Covers such system attributes as feedback loops, response delays, traps, resilience, thresholds and system evolution. Also covers best practices for sustaining complex adaptive systems. (CC) (Prerequisites: ISC 1500, SUS 1500)
courses.subject: SUS
courses.title: Systems Sustainability

courses.description: Requires the design, production and presentation of an individual or group project on improving the sustainable operation of some aspect of the Florida Tech main campus, Florida Tech satellite location or another approved location. (Requirement: Permission of the instructor.) (Q) (Prerequisites: ISC 3999, SUS 3999)
courses.subject: SUS
courses.title: Applied Sustainability

courses.description: Covers advanced aspects of software development and presents issues pertaining to their application to fields such as cybersecurity, embedded systems and machine learning. Discusses agile development methods along with project and quality management aspects for building secure, reliable and maintainable software systems. (Requirement: Background knowledge equivalent to CSE 2010.)
courses.subject: SWE
courses.title: Adv Software Engineering

courses.description: Provides an in-depth study of software requirements engineering tools and techniques. Includes gathering user requirements, formal specification of system behavior, system interfaces, end-user and system documentation and validation techniques. Emphasizes the end-user aspect of gathering and formalizing or user requirements. (Prerequisites: SWE 5001)
courses.subject: SWE
courses.title: Requirements Engineering

courses.description: Teaches advanced skills in test analysis, design and execution. Focuses on exploring testing levels (unit, integration and system testing) and automated testing techniques and tools used in the real world. Acquaints students with testing approaches to validate quality attributes of software systems such as security and reliability. (Prerequisites: SWE 5100, SWE 5120)
courses.subject: SWE
courses.title: Advanced Software Testing

courses.description: Examines common software metrics, axiomatic foundations of measurement, validity of measurements and measurement dysfunction, and some statistical and modeling approaches to help students make their software measurements meaningful. (Prerequisites: CSE 2410, SWE 5001, CSE 2400)
courses.subject: SWE
courses.title: Software Metrics & Modeling

courses.description: Variable registration for thesis completion after satisfaction of minimum registration requirements. (Requirements: Accepted petition to graduate and approval by Office of Graduate Programs.)
courses.subject: SWE
courses.title: Final Semester Thesis

courses.description: Individual work under the direct guidance of a faculty member, culminating in the formal defense of a written thesis. (Requirement: Instructor approval.)
courses.subject: SWE
courses.title: Thesis in SE

courses.description: Provides an in-depth study of systems requirements processes and tools. Includes concepts such as capturing stakeholder requirements, the importance of the concept of operations and the system development life-cycle process. (Requirements: Junior standing and instructor approval.) (Prerequisites: MTH 2201, MTH 3200)
courses.subject: SYS
courses.title: Systems Req Analysis

courses.description: Introduces optical systems engineering and associated principles, methods and techniques. Provides a systems engineering view of the optical system including source characterization, optical propagation, the effects of the atmosphere, optics and imaging, detectors, image and signal processing and displaying the resulting information.
courses.subject: SYS
courses.title: EO Sys Eng

courses.description: Analytical methods to solve decision problems that involve uncertainties, opposing objectives and limited or excessive information. Key topics include structuring decision, expected opportunity loss, expected value of imperfect information, Bayesian Analysis, utility curves, decision trees, risk analysis/mitigation tools and techniques, and risk profiles.
courses.subject: SYS
courses.title: Decisions & Risk Analysis

courses.description: This team-oriented capstone course in the graduating semester enables the student to integrate learning from all MSSE courses in a real-life project setting. Day-to-day progress is monitored by a company supervisor with weekly status reports turned in to the supervisor and the instructor. Input from the company supervisor is a factor in the final grade.
courses.subject: SYS
courses.title: SE Design Project

courses.description: Provides an in-depth study of systems requirements processes and tools. Includes concepts such as capturing stakeholder requirements, the importance of the concept of operations and the system development life-cycle process. (Requirement: Must be enrolled in Systems Engineering.)
courses.subject: SYS
courses.title: Systems Requirements

courses.description: Investigates special interest topics and novel applications or implementations of systems engineering principles under the guidance of graduate faculty. (Requirement: Instructor approval.)
courses.subject: SYS
courses.title: Spec Topics in Sys Eng

courses.description: Individual research under the direction of a member of the graduate faculty in a selected systems engineering topic. May be repeated for a maximum of six credits. (Requirement: Thesis advisor approval.)
courses.subject: SYS
courses.title: Thesis

courses.description: Covers contemporary issues in systems engineering. Includes a wide range of advanced topics such as modern requirements analysis methods, process engineering, decision and risk analysis, engineering modeling and design, team dynamics and productivity, and system analysis and design. (Requirement: Must be enrolled in Systems Engineering.) (Prerequisites: SYS 5310, SYS 5385)
courses.subject: SYS
courses.title: Seminar in SE

courses.description: Preparation of doctoral dissertation. (Requirement: Admission to doctoral candidacy and department head approval.)
courses.subject: SYS
courses.title: Dissertation

courses.description: Provides instruction to students on the writing process with a focus on vocabulary development, sentence structure and paragraph construction. Includes how to develop full-length essays to prepare for higher-level courses. Required for students with writing samples graded three or below. Credit may not be applied toward any Florida Tech degree.
courses.subject: WRI
courses.title: English Writing Review

courses.description: Builds upon the craft, technique and process learned in WRI 2150. Uses the workshop method and analysis of published texts to broaden and deepen understanding of creative writing genres, and develop individual voices. Sharpens writing skills through study of narrative and lyric structures and through revision. (LA) (Prerequisites: WRI 2150)
courses.subject: WRI
courses.title: Advanced Creative Writing
